text: hey everyone my name is Jonathan Woods
and I'm a Solutions architect at
AWS today we are going to talk about the
new cloudfront security
dashboard many customers use services
like web application firewall or wff by
protecting their web applications
against common web exploits and Bots
that can affect availability compromise
security and consume excessive
resources many customers today face the
challenge of implementing security
practices into their existing
workloads some customers know they need
security for their applications but not
everyone is a security expert or has
access to Security Experts this makes it
challenging for customers to put
critical safeguards in place while on
the other hand even when organizations
have access to Security Experts they
don't always have their support for Less
critical projects this requires
customers to navigate security controls
themselves with the new claw front
security dashboard you can now enable
Monitor and manage common security
protections for your web applications
directly from the cloudfront
console the interactive security
dashboard brings W visibility and
controls directly to your Cloud front
distribution including visibility into
your application's top security Trends
allowed and block traffic and Bot
activity investigative tools like a
visual log analyzer and built-in
blocking controls make it easy to
isolate traffic patterns and block
traffic without having to query logs or
right security rules overall this
unified experience centers around high
level workflows so you can focus on
making decisions and taking actions in a
fast and effective
way today we're going to show you four
things first we're going to show you how
to enable the security protections for
your distribution through the cloudfront
cont console along with the w rule
recommendations section for your origin
applications second we'll demonstrate
how you can search directly in the
dashboard and take advantage of dynamic
visual cues like aggregation by IP
address origin country HTTP method and
URI path third we will show you the
ability to dig into bot control for your
applications to easily monitor block or
rate limit Bots such as scrapers
scanners crawlers status monitors and
search
engines and lastly we'll demonstrate the
ability to gather more insights and
granularity into your request with WF
logging let's get
started let's start within the cloud
front console with the new cloudfront
security dashboard release you have a
new security tab on each of your
distributions this is the default view
that you will see if you don't have a
Waf enabled on your distribution already
from here by click clicking edit you can
enable the one-click experience of
turning on a Waf for your cloudfront
distribution with easy to understand
language of the protections included
along with the pricing calculator to
estimate costs based off your regular
monthly request once you save the
changes W will be enabled and your
dashboard will populate with live
traffic within a couple minutes for
demonstration purposes we have traffic
from the past couple of hours and days
displaying as you can see the
recommendations at the top will pop at
with tailored security Amazon managed
rules to enable on your W for your
application below we get to the security
Trends section that provides a bird's
eyee view of your traffic and what your
wife did with it from this view you can
get a sense of how request and traffic
patterns change over the course of the
time window
selected by hovering over request you
see the individual details to better
understand your traffic and gather
individual numbers Additionally you can
see information like what type of attack
types are happening on your application
as well as which countries are hitting
your application the most for our
example we look at this dashboard and
realize that traffic from Aralia should
not be hitting our application from here
you can easily hover over that metric
and turn on blocking control on your
wff what this does in the back end is
creates a rule and places it on your wff
if there isn't one currently if there is
a rule there and you block this country
it will add it to the existing list this
allows you to easily toggle on or off
control for your applications and
security metrics in place without
switching consoles having deep security
expertise or needing to run through
multiple documents to create a w rule
next let's look at the bot control
features within the dashboard by default
bot control is a premium protection and
does not come enabled out of the box on
your W regardless the cloudfront
security dashboard will show you sample
data to see bot requests within the a
lotted Time range selected viewing this
can help you determine if bot control
needs to be enabled for your
applications for example we can see from
our dashboard what traffic is how much
of our traffic is from Bots and which of
these Bots are verified or unverified
for reference Bots self-identify
themselves using the user agent header
for example googlebot but you can't rely
on that value because anyone can write a
script and advertise themselves as
Google bot to address this wbot control
verifies known Bots to ensure that bot's
identity matches who they say they are
when we do we Mark the bot as
verified once you determine that bot
control needs to be enabled you can do
it right from the dashboard without
having to navigate back to the WF
console you can oneclick configure this
feature with the ability to estimate
cost this additional contacts help you
as a customer make the most educated and
correct guess for your security needs
after you save the changes this adds bot
control to your waft configuration and
puts the rule last in your priority list
to help you manage cost putting the rule
last means it will only execute if the
higher priority rules don't trigger on
request with bot control enabled you can
see request categories for each type of
Bot the total number of requests against
your application and what the unverified
bot action
is just as with our earlier example of
setting Geo blocking rules from the
dashboard you can see a bot category
that is currently in monitor mode you
can change that right from the dashboard
to a preferred
action lastly let's look at the logging
section of the dashboard if you do not
have logging enabled for your W you will
see the option to enable logs at the
bottom with one click which allows you
to gather a pricing estimate based off
the number of request per month for your
distribution once enabled the dashboard
creates the cloudwatch log group and
attaches it to your w and begin sending
logs to
cloudwatch with logging enabled this
opens up a lot of possibilities for you
as the customer this allows you to
gather more insights and granularity
into requests within the log section to
investigate security Trends while
allowing you the ability to filter on
different
criteria let's dig a Little Deeper to
see what's going on with our traffic for
example let's assume we notice some
unusual requests for a PHP my admin path
and we want to uncover some information
about the
request I can search for those to easily
gain insightful information about the
request to determine the legitimacy of
that traffic from here you can see
information like request path IP address
country origin and action taken on each
request this helps you visualize
patterns in your logs that would be
otherwise difficult to spot if you only
had the raw log
lines taking our example if a
disproportionate amount of traffic is
coming from a single IP address
particular countries where you don't
expect traffic or targeting a specific
URI path the cloudfront security
dashboard provides easy access to take
necessary
actions in closing what we've seen today
is the new claw front security dashboard
the interactive security dashboard
brings W visibility and controls

including visibility into your
